diagrams.caption: Sparse Pauli-Lindblad noise learning: calibration circuits characterize the noise as low-weight Pauli errors, the sparse Lindblad model is fit, and the model enables scalable probabilistic error cancellation by efficient inversion.

description: Sparse Pauli-Lindblad (SPL) noise learning is a scalable protocol for characterizing quantum noise that enables probabilistic error cancellation on large quantum processors. The key innovation is modeling noise as a Lindblad master equation with sparse, low-weight Pauli jump operators, capturing correlated errors (including crosstalk) while remaining efficiently learnable and invertible.

Traditional noise characterization methods like full process tomography scale exponentially with qubit count, making them impractical for modern processors. SPL overcomes this by assuming sparsity: noise is dominated by low-weight Pauli errors on neighboring qubits. This assumption holds well in practice for superconducting and trapped-ion systems.

Once learned, the SPL model can be efficiently inverted for probabilistic error cancellation, or used to inject calibrated noise for zero-noise extrapolation (as in PEA). This unified noise representation enabled the landmark 127-qubit utility demonstration, where accurate observable estimation was achieved despite running 60 layers of two-qubit gates.
how_it_works: Run calibration circuits: typically randomized benchmarking-style circuits that probe the noise channel for each layer of entangling gates.
Fit a sparse Pauli-Lindblad model: express the noise channel as \(\mathcal{N}(\rho) = e^{\mathcal{L}}\rho\) where the Lindbladian \(\mathcal{L}\) has sparse Pauli jump operators.
The sparsity assumption restricts to low-weight Pauli errors (typically weight 1-2) on geometrically local qubits, dramatically reducing the number of parameters.
Estimate the Lindblad rates \(\lambda_i\) for each sparse Pauli error channel from the calibration data.
For PEC: invert the learned noise model to construct the quasi-probability decomposition of ideal gates.
For PEA/ZNE: use the learned model to inject additional noise proportionally, achieving accurate noise amplification.

advantages: Scales to large quantum processors (demonstrated on 127 qubits)
Captures correlated noise including crosstalk between neighboring qubits
Efficiently learnable: polynomial number of parameters in qubit count
Efficiently invertible: enables practical PEC at scale
Unified model for both PEC (inversion) and PEA/ZNE (noise amplification)
Validated extensively on IBM superconducting hardware
disadvantages: Sparsity assumption may not hold for all noise types (e.g., long-range correlations)
Calibration overhead: requires running characterization circuits
Model may drift between calibration and experiment execution
Learning high-weight correlations (weight > 2) increases cost significantly
use_cases: Enabling PEC on large-scale quantum processors
Accurate noise amplification for ZNE via probabilistic error amplification (PEA)
Any QEM workflow requiring scalable noise characterization
